name: ammonium paratungstate production, solvent extraction | ammonium paratungstate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23559/documentation

This dataset is a copy of the global dataset. It represents the production of 1 Kg ammonium paratungstate (APT) by hydrometallurgy. ATP has the chemical formula (NH4)10(H2W12O42) 4H2O and is the most important intermediate product for all tungsten products (Lassner et al. 2000). Due to lack of data, this dataset does not include any recycling processes. However, it should be noted that global tungsten recycling rates are between 10-24 % (after use) (Furberg et al. 2019). Considering tungsten scrap as an input will therefore impact this dataset significantly. ;;The data for this dataset is taken from a LCI provided by Furberg et al. (2019) which was build based on data from literature.  ;Furberg, A., Arvidsson, R., Molander, S., 2019. Environmental life cycle assessment of cemented carbide (WC-Co) production. J. Clean. Prod. 209, 1126-1138. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.10.272;;;Lassner, E., Schubert, W.-D., Lüderitz, E., Wolf, H.U., 2000. Tungsten, Tungsten Alloys, and Tungsten Compounds. In "Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry". Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim, Germany, pp. 1-53. https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a27_229

	The activity starts when the raw material enters the process

This activity ends with the production of 1 Kg APT.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Inputs for water used for washing and inputs related to solvent extraction (organic solvent, H2SO4 so-lution, deionized H2O and NH3) are based on a publication from 1979: Yih, S.W.H., Wang, C.T., 1979. Tungsten - Sources, Metallurgy, Properties and Applications.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents APT production in the US using solvent extraction (liquid ion extraction -LIX), which is the technology used globally with the exception of China where solid ion extraction is used instead (Lassner and Schubert 1999). ;Lassner, E., Schubert, W.-D., 1999. Tungsten "Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. Springer US, Boston, MA. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4615-4907-9
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset represents the production of APT using solvent extraction (liquid ion extraction -LIX). Digestion is performed with NaOH solution in the case of wolframite concnetrate and Na2CO3 solution in the case of scheelite concentrate in order to obtain a sodium tungstate (Na2WO4) solution. The sodium tungstate solution is purified by filtration and precipitation. Precipitation of dissolved silicates is carried out by adding aluminum sulfate solution or magnesium sulfate solution. Molybdenum and other elements forming insoluble sulfides (As, Sb, Bi, Pb, Fe, Ni, and Co) are precipitated by the addition of an excess of sodium hydrosulfide and acidification with sulfuric acid. Finally, the purified Na2WO4 solution is converted to ammonium tungstate solution using solvent extraction and APT is formed by crystallization;Furberg, A., Arvidsson, R., Molander, S., 2019. Environmental life cycle assessment of cemented carbide (WC-Co) production. J. Clean. Prod. 209, 1126-1138. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.10.272;Lassner, E., Schubert, W.-D., Lüderitz, E., Wolf, H.U., 2000. Tungsten, Tungsten Alloys, and Tungsten Compounds. In "Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry". Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim, Germany, pp. 1-53. https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a27_229
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset was extrapolated from the global dataset.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Based on literature data: 

Furberg, A., Arvidsson, R., Molander, S., 2019. Environmental life cycle assessment of cemented carbide (WC-Co) production. J. Clean. Prod. 209, 1126-1138. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.10.272
